Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s a ritual as sacred as any prayer, a time to hear my mother’s gentle voice and my father’s quiet laughter. They wait for my call, eager for stories from my week, and I know it means the world to them. But tonight, the main weekly service at the temple has been rescheduled—moved to the same hour as my call. The community expects me to lead; they rely on my presence, my words, my prayers. I can already picture the congregation gathering, waiting for me to guide them. My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call home.” My heart aches, torn between the duty to my parents and the responsibility to my community. Both expect my time, my attention, my care. I stare at the phone, the temple bell echoing in the distance, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which voice to answer first.
